choices.A: It increases the number of controls required to subvert a system
choices.B: It decreases the time a CERT has to respond to a security incident.
choices.D: It allows for bandwidth upgrades to be made without user disruption.
choices.C: It alleviates problems associated with EOL equipment replacement.

comments.content: It's A because if you have layered security then if the first layer get's broken then the their is another layers that needs to be broken before the attacker can get to your system.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the primary reason for implementing layered security measures in a cybersecurity architecture?

choices.A: A spear-phishing email with a file attachment.
choices.D: A domain hijacking of a bank website
choices.C: An evil twin wireless access point

discussion.content: Spear phishing happens when an innocent victim responds to a fraudulent email request demanding action. This action can include providing passwords, credit card .
Another vague question , which can be moulded to use different answers
Only logical one is choice A.

questions.question_text: Which of the following attacks can be used to exploit a vulnerability that was created by untrained users?

A company uses an enterprise desktop imaging solution to manage deployment of its desktop computers. Desktop computer users are only permitted to use software that is part of the baseline image. Which of the following technical solutions was MOST likely deployed by the company to ensure only known-good software can be installed on corporate desktops?

discussion.content: Could configuration manager also be an option?

questions.question_text: A company recently experienced a security incident in which its domain controllers were the target of a DoS attack. In which of the following steps should technicians connect domain controllers to the network and begin authenticating users again?

discussion.content: Some direct questions in damn complex ones!
A is wrong, B sound weird, as vulnerability scan is signature nature I would go for C.

comments.content:
Can't confirm in my books but this seems to fortify your and idolL's thoughts:
"A false positive might occur when the scanner can read only the configuration information from service banners. For example, a scanner that reads an Apache banner can detect that only version 2.2.15 is installed from the HTTP banner, even when version 2.2.15-39 is also installed and that the version contains a software fix that was backported. " https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/en/SSKMKU/com.ibm.qradar.doc/c_qvm_false_positive_vulns.html

discussion.content: (A) is not correct, because "false positive" means the scan found something (even though there is no vulnerability).

Answer is D . they ask what could return false positive , well from all answers "The hosts are evaluated based on an OS-specific profile.". If you run OS specific VS against OS which does not match, what would you expect to happen.

comments.content: Comptia exam writers need the D
That's correct. Guys please read it and you will come to D. Who needs the d

discussion.content: I think there is no correct answer for this question.

comments.content: possibly the worst answer i've came across yet

The given answer is correct. The computer clock/time is out of sync with the NTP/server protocol. So, Yes the vulnerability does not exist at that time for that node. Reboot the computer so that the clock /time can sync to the correct current time. We had to do this as part of our turnover routine when we were starting and leaving our shifts when I worked as a datacenter tech.

discussion.content:
A would be correct if the question were "Which of the following explains why a vulnerability scan might return a false negative?" Not false positive.
False positive = The vulnerability does not exist.
False negative = The vulnerability exists, but not detected.
I have found "B" as the correct answer on several different sites and in my text book.
A would be false negative...Not sure what correct answer is either C or D but def not A
The scan is performed at a time of day when the vulnerability does not exist. <= Zero-Day
shouldn't be B? any help please?

questions.question_text: Which of the following explains why a vulnerability scan might return a false positive?

choices.D: The hosts are evaluated based on an OS-specific profile.
choices.C: The signature matches the product but not the version information.
choices.A: The scan is performed at a time of day when the vulnerability does not exist.
choices.B: The test is performed against the wrong host.
